quoteLast: the enemy started a heavy bombardment. About 7 a.m. enemy infantry attacked and gained a footing in the forward trench and commenced to work round our left in considerable numbers.
title: The History of the 7th Battalion Queen's Own Cameron Highlanders

quoteFirst: "Yes; she was brought in on Wednesday morning
quoteLast: by a police constable who had been on night duty in Regent's Park. He saw her knocked down by a man, and picked her up unconscious, and she has been so ever since. The man got away in the dark, and at the hospital no one recognised the young lady from the description given in the inquiries that were made, as the account of the clothes she wore was all wrong.
title: Mrs. Vanderstein's jewels

quoteFirst: The fifth shock (E, Fig. 63) occurred at
quoteLast: , and disturbed an area 104 miles in length, 79 miles in width, and about 6,400 square miles in area. Its boundary occupies approximately the position that would be taken by an isoseismal of intensity between 7 and 6 of the principal earthquake.

quoteFirst: Under date of November 16 he writes: "I am in a most nervous state on account of having had three days and nights of successive earthquakes--fearful ones. The first night I walked the streets, and indeed every one else did the same; the second night I went to bed quite exhausted at
quoteLast: ; last night also at about 2 A.M., but I could not sleep, for we had about six shocks, though not so strong. The whole cornice of a house close to ours came down into the street, but luckily no one was passing at the time.
title:
Harper's Young People, June 1, 1880
An Illustrated Weekly
author: Various

quoteFirst: Throughout the night it stormed violently,-- rain, hail, snow, and sleet beating upon the vessel,-- the wind continuing ahead, and the sea running high. At daybreak (
quoteLast: ) the deck was covered with snow. The captain sent up the steward with a glass of grog to each of the watch; and all the time that we were off the Cape, grog was given to the morning watch, and to all hands whenever we reefed topsails.
title: Two Years Before the Mast
author: Dana, Richard Henry, 1815-1882

quoteFirst: We awoke next day to find ourselves in the southern hemisphere, having crossed the line
quoteLast: As the morning wore on we passed abreast of the Cabo San Lorenzo, and towards evening, keeping nearer to the coast, were within a few miles of Cabo Santa Elena. This forms the north-western headland of the Gulf of Guayaquil, a wide bay that extends fully a hundred miles eastward from the coastline.
title: Notes of a naturalist in South America
author: Ball, John, 1818-1889
